user_request: Write a Shakespearean sonnet about a traveler at a fork in a yellow wood.
final_poem:
Where two paths diverge in the yellow wood,
the sun's thin finger cannot pierce them both—
one winding down into a darker shroud,
the other lifting toward some fainter star.  

I stand, that traveler whose footfall is wet,
and feel the earth shift under my one shoe.
Which way the heart will turn its single met,
I cannot know until I turn and go.

But something in me doubts the path that climbs
past bracken dead against a bruised heaven—
it looks too much like all those upward aims
my restless years have made, and little won.

So let me try the other. If it bends
to darkness, at least I went that way fully, spun.
